Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the extent to which Missouri has more crime percentage-wise than the rest of the country.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that Missouri has more crime percentage-wise than the rest of the country.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the overall crime rate throughout the country is going down, which may not be supported by the available data.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the difference in crime rates between Missouri and the rest of the country that are not considered in the claim.
Understate: The claim may be understating the decrease in crime rates in Missouri by focusing on the increase over a five-year period rather than the recent decrease in the past year.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Missouri's violent crime rate decreased by 5.2% in the last year, while the rest of the country saw a 3% decrease.
Falters at times: The claim falters by relying on outdated statistics from 2011 and not considering more recent data.
